>Was there any research along these lines that you read
>beforehand?  Or has anyone else seen this approach to
>board analysis/game play?

I seem to remember a mention of something like this in terms of
shape-recognition (albeit simpler) in a SANE paper, but I can't remember
which one. As for game play, I've never heard of anyone trying it, but it
certainly sounds like an interesting idea, especially applied to Go. Clearly
it would make the network more easily able to recognise localised patterns.

>Did you toy around with any of these ideas before
>settling on your approach?

I didn't think of zooming, but the vector idea was roughly similar to the
continuous-space variant I tried, where the network outputs the distance it
wants to travel horizontally and vertically, rather than just taking >.5 to
mean a boolean output. What I mean is this:-

X1=output 1 ("left")
X2=output 2 ("right")
Y1=output 1 ("up")
Y2=output 2 ("down")

new X coord=old X coord+X2-X1
new Y coord=old Y coord+Y2-Y1

Now, in your case you'd probably want to scale the outputs up a bit so it
would move in larger jumps more easily.

I should say this variant didn't do nearly as well as the discrete grid in
the tests (see below).

>Hmm...and what was their success rate in guessing the
>correct shape (I'm assuming they eventually evolved to
>guess better than chance).

100% after 1590 generations.

The continuous-space variant, on my best run, 93% after 2890 generations. At
that point, evolution had seemed to stagnate a bit.

>There's actually a "Files"
>section on the Yahoo Groups page.

OK, I'll look into that a little later today.

--Darren
